body:
pls run the entire asv suite. I think you are copying unecessarily in a few places. This needs to be a *very* narrow change.

IOW, *only* when a copy is specify requested on the entire DataFrame, e.g. ``df.iloc[:]`` or ``df.loc[:]``. NOT anyother time as they return view by-definition.
@jreback Okay, I can revert the change for the tuple cases. I was going off of this comment on the original issue https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/13873#issuecomment-236717538
@margaret yes, this is *only* for all null slices passed. You have to be *very* careful with copying as that can really change performance. We always return views.

I think we should probably only be shallow copying in these cases (`.copy(deep=False)`)  - seems to be consistent with numpy semantics.

```
a = np.array([1, 2, 3])

a[:] is a
Out[44]: False

In [46]: a[:].base is a
Out[46]: True
```

Ran all the tests locally (but only on Python 2.7). Currently failing two tests: [`test_sorting.py`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/pandas/tests/series/test_sorting.py#L84) for `Series` that was implemented for issue https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/5856 which was fixed with PR https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/5853

```python
        # GH 5856/5853
        # Series.sort_values operating on a view
        df = DataFrame(np.random.randn(10, 4))
        s = df.iloc[:, 0]

        def f():
            s.sort_values(inplace=True)

        pytest.raises(ValueError, f)
```
and something in `check_round_trip_frame` in [`test_clipboard.py`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/pandas/tests/io/test_clipboard.py#L69)
```python
    def check_round_trip_frame(self, data_type, excel=None, sep=None,
                               encoding=None):
        data = self.data[data_type]
        data.to_clipboard(excel=excel, sep=sep, encoding=encoding)
        if sep is not None:
            result = read_clipboard(sep=sep, index_col=0, encoding=encoding)
        else:
            result = read_clipboard(encoding=encoding)
        tm.assert_frame_equal(data, result, check_dtype=False)
```
which raises
```
E       AssertionError: DataFrame are different
E       
E       DataFrame shape mismatch
E       [left]:  (2, 2)
E       [right]: (0, 1)

pandas/util/testing.py:1109: AssertionError
```

Looking into these.

The clipboard one is a flaky test, I'd ignore it - other failure probably is legitimate.

Can you also run the performance benchmarks to see if anything was impacted? Docs here:
http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/contributing.html#running-the-performance-test-suite
Yep, looks like it is just the sorting a view test that's failing.

Calling `df.iloc[:,0]`, down in 
```
-> s = df.iloc[:, 0]
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(1325)__getitem__()
-> return self._getitem_tuple(key)
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(1664)_getitem_tuple()
-> return self._getitem_lowerdim(tup)
> /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(992)_getitem_lowerdim()
-> return getattr(section, self.name)[new_key]
```
when parsing the `0`, it ends up calling and returning `iloc[:]` https://github.com/margaret/pandas/blob/bb1b9c90e43a1ffcc61d4a0056e6439eb57502ea/pandas/core/indexing.py#L992
So that would return a copy of the `section` (the column) as a new object instead of the original column which here was actually a view into the ndarray.
Python 3.6 tests passed locally. Running benchmarks â³
Travis failure is on `ci/lint.sh`, but `git diff upstream/master --name-only -- '*.py' | flake8 --diff` passes, going to try running that locally.

Also the benchmarks are about 2/3 done now (have to go soon but will resume later), but there have been 3 failures (below). Going to look into that but if anyone has thoughts please share.
```
[  0.00%] Â· For pandas commit hash b904308f:
...
[ 33.22%] Â·Â·Â· Running panel_methods.PanelMethods.time_pct_change_items 
[ 33.29%] Â·Â·Â· Running panel_methods.PanelMethods.time_pct_change_major
[ 33.36%] Â·Â·Â· Running panel_methods.PanelMethods.time_pct_change_minor
```
asv benchmark results in this [gist](https://gist.github.com/margaret/489f8b5a8e6e8eb754a01df0c425dbb7). ðŸ¤”

@margaret a couple (very tiny) linting errors :) https://travis-ci.org/pandas-dev/pandas/jobs/235411163

```
pandas/tests/indexing/test_iloc.py:599:16: E714 test for object identity should be 'is not'
pandas/tests/indexing/test_loc.py:638:16: E714 test for object identity should be 'is not'
```

both loc and iloc should return shallow copies for [:]

Indexing with a single loc or iloc call otherwise should always return a view, right? In v0.21.0 `df.iloc[:,0]` on a df created from a 2d ndarray returns a different object than `df[0]`. So is that actually incorrect behavior?

> Indexing with a single loc or iloc call otherwise should always return a view, right? In v0.21.0 df.iloc[:,0] on a df created from a 2d ndarray returns a different object than df[0]. So is that actually incorrect behavior?

can you show a specific example.

```
>>> pd.__version__
'0.20.1'
>>> df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(10, 4))
>>> df.loc[:,0] is df[0]
True
>>> df.iloc[:,0] is df[0]
False
```
@margaret hmm, those should both be views. was this changed from 0.19.2?

Nope, looks like it's the same in 0.19.2. I think it's [this line where Series.from_array is called](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/pandas/core/frame.py#L2095) in `DataFrame._ixs` that's creating a new object, since `section` [here](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/pandas/core/indexing.py#L967) is what's being returned. Weird though since default for `from_array` is `copy=False`

```
-> df.iloc[:,0]
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(1330)__getitem__()
-> return self._getitem_tuple(key)
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(1669)_getitem_tuple()
-> return self._getitem_lowerdim(tup)
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(968)_getitem_lowerdim()
-> section = self._getitem_axis(key, axis=i)
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(1756)_getitem_axis()
-> return self._get_loc(key, axis=axis)
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(139)_get_loc()
-> return self.obj._ixs(key, axis=axis)
> /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/frame.py(2096)_ixs()
-> result = self._constructor_sliced.from_array(values,
```

edit: Hm, looks like `loc` here ultimately just calls `df[0]`
```
-> df.loc[:,0]
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(1329)__getitem__()
-> return self._getitem_tuple(key)
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(836)_getitem_tuple()
-> return self._getitem_lowerdim(tup)
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(967)_getitem_lowerdim()
-> section = self._getitem_axis(key, axis=i)
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(1556)_getitem_axis()
-> return self._get_label(key, axis=axis)
  /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/indexing.py(136)_get_label()
-> return self.obj._xs(label, axis=axis)
> /Users/margaret/Documents/Projects/pandas/pandas/core/generic.py(1932)xs()
-> return self[key]
```

yeah we prob don't systematically check this
welcome for u to open a new issue / PR for that
@margaret lgtm. can you add the same tests for ``df[:]`` and ``s[:]`` they should do the same.
